In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

In Julia, you can write a function `wrap_string` that wraps the text at a specified width by using a combination of `split` and `join`. Here's an example:

```julia
function wrap_string(text::String; text_width::Int=10)
    lines = split(text, " ")
    wrapped_lines = Vector{String}()
    current_line = String[]
    for word in lines
        if length(current_line) == 0 || (length(current_line) + length(word) + 1) <= text_width
            # Append the word to the current line
            push!(current_line, word)
        else
            # Wrap and add the current line, then start a new one
            push!(wrapped_lines, join(current_line))
            current_line = [word]
        end
    end
    # Add the last line if it has content
    if length(current_line) > 0
        push!(wrapped_lines, join(current_line))
    end
    return join(wrapped_lines, "\n")
end
```

This function splits the text into words and then builds an array of strings where each element is a line. It does this by keeping track of the current line and adding new lines when the width limit is reached. The `text_width` parameter controls how many characters can be on a single line before wrapping occurs.

Here's an example of how to use the function:

```julia
julia> wrap_string("Hello there this is a very long sentence that will wrap because it's longer than 10 characters per line")
"Hello there\nthis is a very long sentence\nthat will wrap because it's longer than\n10 characters per line"
```

In this example, the text is wrapped at approximately every 10 characters (the `text_width` value), resulting in three lines of text.
